greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct twin prime pairs p, p+2 such that both of them divide n.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..100000
example: For n = 45 = 3^2 * 5, there exists one twin prime pair (3,5) whose both members divide 45, thus a(45) = 1.
For n = 105 = 3 * 5 * 7, there exists two twin prime pairs, (3,5) and (5,7) whose both members divide 105, thus a(105) = 2.
mathematica: f[p_, n_] := If[PrimeQ[p + 2] && Divisible[n, p*(p + 2)], 1, 0]; a[n_] := Plus @@ (f[#, n] & /@ FactorInteger[n][[;; , 1]]); Array[a, 105] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Dec 16 2018 *)
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 16 2018
